paragraphs.body: In 1961 and 1962, Stone was twice cast in different roles on ABC's The Real McCoys in the episodes "Money from Heaven" and "You Can't Beat the Army". Between 1962 and 1966, Stone made four guest appearances on CBS' Perry Mason. In his 1962 role he played murderer Jerel Leland in "The Case of the Hateful Hero". He played popular and memorable characters on The Outer Limits, Sanford and Son, Lost in Space, and M*A*S*H. He appeared twice on ABC's The Donna Reed Show as Mr. Trestle in the 1961 episode "The Good Guys and the Bad Guys" and in 1965 as Harlan Carmody Jr. in "Joe College".
paragraphs.text: In 1961 and 1962, Stone was twice cast in different roles on ABC's The Real McCoys in the episodes "Money from Heaven" and "You Can't Beat the Army". Between 1962 and 1966, Stone made four guest appearances on CBS' Perry Mason. In his 1962 role he played murderer Jerel Leland in "The Case of the Hateful Hero". He played popular and memorable characters on The Outer Limits, Sanford and Son, Lost in Space, and M*A*S*H. He appeared twice on ABC's The Donna Reed Show as Mr. Trestle in the 1961 episode "The Good Guys and the Bad Guys" and in 1965 as Harlan Carmody Jr. in "Joe College".

paragraphs.body: In 1966, he had a supporting role as Morton on the short-lived CBS sitcom The Jean Arthur Show, starring Jean Arthur and Ron Harper. Between 1988 and 1994 he appeared in twelve episodes of the NBC legal drama L.A. Law as Judge Paul Hanson. On September 22, 2000, Stone appeared as an ordinary, non-celebrity contestant on the popular game show Wheel of Fortune. He placed second, winning $4,250 in cash and a trip to Bermuda valued at $5,310.
paragraphs.text: In 1966, he had a supporting role as Morton on the short-lived CBS sitcom The Jean Arthur Show, starring Jean Arthur and Ron Harper. Between 1988 and 1994 he appeared in twelve episodes of the NBC legal drama L.A. Law as Judge Paul Hanson. On September 22, 2000, Stone appeared as an ordinary, non-celebrity contestant on the popular game show Wheel of Fortune. He placed second, winning $4,250 in cash and a trip to Bermuda valued at $5,310.

paragraphs.body: One of his earlier notables came in 1971 when he played Sam Beauregarde, the father of golden ticket winner Violet Beauregarde, in Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory.
paragraphs.text: One of his earlier notables came in 1971 when he played Sam Beauregarde, the father of golden ticket winner Violet Beauregarde, in Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory.

paragraphs.body: Stone's final role came in 2006 at the age of eighty-three, when he played a minor character in the TV movie Surrender, Dorothy.
paragraphs.text: Stone's final role came in 2006 at the age of eighty-three, when he played a minor character in the TV movie Surrender, Dorothy.
